TEXT: CARDINAL . In DATE Mr PERSON was a warder at FAC ( GPE ) , having previously worked at FAC until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON , an inmate of ORG serving a life sentence imposed by ORG , attempted to escape . Using a revolver which he had managed to obtain clandestinely , he took the chief warder hostage , but another warder succeeded in disarming him . A note signed by PERSON was found on him ; it was undated and read as follows :
" I hereby promise to pay the sum of MONEY by CARDINAL or DATE . "
When questioned by the GPE police and an investigating judge , he first refused to disclose where the weapon had come from , and then stated that he had been given it by the applicant .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was charged on the following day by the investigating judge of ORG ( tribunal de première instance ) .

He was detained on DATE and denied that he had provided the weapon . He admitted having written and signed the document , but claimed that he had given it to another inmate , PERSON , from whom he said he had borrowed the sum of MONEY to pay gambling debts .
CARDINAL . The detention order was confirmed on several occasions in DATE .

CARDINAL . Mr Derriks , the Deputy Director of ORG , indicated that he had new information for the investigators , and was interviewed on DATE by the police inspector assigned to the inquiry . He stated as follows :
" For DATE there have been rumours among the prisoners in C wing suggesting that the former warder , PERSON , was not the person who brought into the prison the revolver used by PERSON .

More recently , on DATE , I saw the inmate PERSON in an office of our prison . I had to inform him of an internal administrative decision . On that occasion PERSON told me that he wished to give me information confided in him by other inmates of C wing . He said that the weapon used by PERSON had been introduced into the prison initially for the use of the prisoner PERSON by a certain PERSON , a visitor of the prisoner PERSON . After she had smuggled the weapon into the prison and hidden it in the visitors’ lavatory , PERSON had escaped when , on DATE , he had been taken for a medical examination at FAC . The weapon remained in the prison and finally ended up in the hands of PERSON , who had planned to escape with PERSON using the weapon .

According to PERSON , after it had been brought into the building , the weapon was hidden at the bottom of a dustbin , which PERSON alone , as a server , had the possibility of using as a hiding place for DATE .
I must inform you that PERSON made this statement spontaneously , but hoping to increase his chances of release on licence .
I would add that PERSON has still not been re - arrested since his escape on DATE and that PERSON , nicknamed the ‘ C wing FAC , was provisionally released , with a view to deportation , on DATE .
The latter ’s visitor may be identified as : PERSON ... , or her sister PERSON , ...
Again according to PERSON , PERSON is totally unconnected with the bringing into the prison of these weapons .
CARDINAL . The investigators tried to question the persons referred to in the above statement .
On DATE Mr PERSON reaffirmed before the investigating judge that the applicant had provided him with the weapon , in exchange for payment of MONEY .

PERSON , who was questioned in prison on DATE , refused to say anything , for fear of provoking animosity from the other inmates . He added that he would report of his own accord to the investigating judge once he had obtained his release on licence , and that he would give evidence in ORG if , by then , he was back with his family so that he could protect them from any reprisals by Mr PERSON .

On DATE the police questioned Miss PERSON , who denied the accusation that she had introduced a weapon for the use of Mr GPE , a close friend of her sister PERSON . She stated that , although they used her address , Mr PERSON and her sister lived elsewhere .

Mr PERSON and Miss PERSON were summoned to appear on DATE . They telephoned the investigators on DATE to tell them that for personal reasons they were unable to appear for the time being but they were willing to come forward at DATE . They did not comply with CARDINAL further summonses . On DATE the investigators informed the investigating judge that the CARDINAL persons concerned had left their residence for an unknown destination , and that Mr GPE , a foreign national , had been released provisionally shortly before and was subject to a deportation order .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( chambre du conseil ) rescinded the detention order concerning the applicant . Its decision was confirmed by ORG ( chambre des mises en accusation ) on DATE .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was sent for trial before ORG , charged with :

" A. on DATE ... as an accessory ... having procured weapons which were used to commit a criminal offence , knowing that they were intended to be so used , or having knowingly aided or abetted the perpetrator of the offence ... in respect of action which prepared or facilitated the offence or which carried it out , having attempted to take a hostage , by holding , detaining or seizing PERSON , a prison warder , in order to ... prepare or facilitate the escape [ of PERSON , the intention to commit the offence having been manifested by conduct which objectively constituted the first step towards the perpetration of the offence and which conduct was halted or failed to attain the aim pursued only as a result of circumstances outside the control of its perpetrators .

B. ... having , between CARDINAL DATE and DATE , being the officer on duty with responsibility for an inmate convicted of a criminal offence , namely , PERSON , facilitated the latter ’s escape by supplying him with a weapon , the said escape having been attempted using violence or threats .
C. ... having , in DATE , prior to DATE , over an unspecified period , had in his possession a firearm without having duly registered it .
E. ... having , in DATE or DATE , at a date as yet undetermined , sold a firearm to a person who was neither a manufacturer nor an arms dealer nor in possession of an authorisation to purchase it .
On DATE the court acquitted him on the following grounds :

It is not possible on the basis of the case - file or the evidence adduced at the hearing to form , beyond all possible doubt , a conviction as to the ... defendant ’s guilt ; the statements , albeit categorical , [ of PERSON ] can not in fact be verified by any specific objective evidence in the case - file ;
In the same judgment , it convicted Mr PERSON and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .
At the hearing on DATE the court had heard the applicant and PERSON , and had also taken evidence from CARDINAL prison warders and QUANTITY police officers .

CARDINAL . The prosecution and the civil party seeking damages appealed . By a unanimous judgment of DATE , ORG sentenced Mr PERSON to CARDINAL GPE imprisonment , the part of the sentence exceeding the time spent in detention on remand being suspended for DATE .
It found that :

" ... the co - defendant ’s accusations have remained consistent although he had no interest in ... securing [ the applicant ’s ] downfall , and in addition to other information in the case - file concerning the defendant ’s financial circumstances and conduct , the latter having admitted borrowing money from a prisoner , they give rise to serious , precise and concurring presumptions which constitute proof of the charges ... "
At the same time it confirmed the sentence imposed on PERSON at first instance .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON appealed , and ORG quashed the judgment on CARDINAL DATE , on the grounds that ORG had been presided over by a judge who had on CARDINAL DATE presided over ORG when it had confirmed a decision of ORG refusing to order the appellant ’s release , and , having regard to Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the LAW , on which he had relied , such a circumstance could arouse in the appellant " a legitimate doubt as to the ability of ORG ... to hear the case in an impartial manner . "

CARDINAL . On an application by PERSON , the principal public prosecutor of ORG , to which the case had been remitted , sent the public prosecutor of ORG ) a letter of request on DATE asking him to question PERSON , who had in the meantime been arrested in GPE and was being held at FAC . He was questioned by the NORP police on DATE and denied having lent the applicant MONEY . The record of his statements was added to the applicant ’s case - file .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , by a unanimous decision , sentenced Mr PERSON to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . The court gave the following reasons for its decision :

A detailed examination of the evidence in the case - file and of the evidence adduced at the hearing has enabled the court to form the conviction that the defendant is guilty of the offences as charged ;
This conviction is based on CARDINAL items of evidence which are complementary :
( CARDINAL ) the statements of PERSON ; ( CARDINAL ) the promissory note signed by PERSON ;
( CARDINAL ) The statements of PERSON

Notwithstanding the caution with which the statements of a person such as ORG should be treated , the court is bound to observe that the accusations which he levelled against PERSON have remained consistent throughout the investigation and that the statements which he made on numerous occasions both when questioned by the police and on examination by the investigating judge are precise and coherent ;

In addition it should be stressed that the case - file contains no evidence to support the claim that there was between PERSON and PERSON a matter of dispute or disagreement capable of explaining or justifying the accusation made by the latter against the former ;
PERSON himself has not cited in this respect any reason for his accuser to bear ill - feelings against him ;
The defendant unsuccessfully alleged in his submissions that ORG statements were improbable in numerous respects and contained discrepancies ;

The court is bound to note that , as regards the essential question , namely the allegation that PERSON supplied PERSON with the firearm which was used to carry out the escape attempt , PERSON has never altered his statements ;
In short , these statements at no time appeared improbable or incoherent ; on the contrary , they are highly believable and capable of sustaining the conviction formed by the court ;
( CARDINAL ) The promissory note signed by PERSON
It is established that a document constituting a promissory note for a sum of MONEY , signed by PERSON , was discovered in the search made of PERSON after his abortive escape attempt ;

The court notes that the existence of this document accordingly constitutes an objective fact which corroborates PERSON accusations and shows that there existed between the CARDINAL men business relations of which the least that can be said is that they were unacceptable as far as PERSON was concerned because of his duties as a prison warder and that these relations were such as to undermine his independence vis - à - vis prisoners ;
Although he is unable to deny that he had contracted a debt , he has unsuccessfully alleged that he had borrowed the sum from another inmate ;

This statement , in the first place , is formally contested both by PERSON and the other prisoner , a certain PERSON , and secondly , is not at all consistent with the fact that the disputed document was found in PERSON hands ;
It is hard to see why the promissory note should be among the documents in PERSON possession if PERSON had not been his debtor ;

These CARDINAL objective items of evidence , which are in no way incompatible with all the other evidence regarding the defendant ’s conduct in relation to the inmates ( borrowing sums of money from them , abnormal familiarity , serious failures to carry out proper surveillance ) , are sufficient to lead the court to form its conviction ;
The first - instance court wrongly found that charges A , B and E were not established ; it did not rule on charge C ;

These CARDINAL charges [ see paragraph CARDINAL above ] are established ; the offences referred to therein are a manifestation of a single criminal intention and justify the imposition of CARDINAL sentence , the heaviest of those applicable ;
The offences committed by the defendant are extremely serious ones ;

By facilitating by supplying a weapon the escape of a prisoner serving life imprisonment , even though the escape failed because of circumstances outside his control , the defendant PERSON endangered the lives of certain of his fellow - warders who , like him , were on duty with responsibility for prisoners ;
Such actions must be punished by a sentence commensurate with their seriousness , and the imposition of any suspended sentence is consequently out of the question ;
CARDINAL . In submissions of CARDINAL DATE counsel for the defence had asked the court :
As principal submission
To hold that each and every charge brought against the defendant PERSON is not established , to find him not guilty and acquit him .
In the alternative

To carry out all appropriate additional investigative measures , and in any event to order PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , all detained in FAC at the time of the alleged offences , to be called as witnesses ... "
With respect to PERSON , the application was based on the following considerations ( pp . DATE and CARDINAL of the said submissions ) :
Short statement of the facts
CARDINAL . During the investigation ...

In DATE , following rumours which had circulated persistently for DATE in C wing of ORG ( PERSON had not been inside this prison since being arrested on DATE , hence no contact with the prisoners in that wing ) , it had turned out , according to these rumours among prisoners , that it had not been PERSON who had introduced the revolver ‘ used by PERSON Hernandez’ ...

On DATE prisoner PERSON reported these rumours and gave full details as to how the weapon had been introduced and the persons involved - directly or indirectly : PERSON , another server in C wing when being visited by his friend PERSON of the weapon , passing it to PERSON , finally reaching PERSON .
PERSON escaped on DATE .
PERSON released on licence and deported in DATE .
N.B. No detailed investigation took place regarding these facts .
PERSON was not even questioned by the investigating judge , although he had promised [ the police ] that he would give evidence ( i.e. on oath ) before ORG if necessary ...
Critical appreciation of the investigation ...

CARDINAL . The Deputy Director of ORG , Mr Derriks , considered it his duty to bring to the attention of the judicial authorities certain facts ( which he thus considered to be sufficiently important ) , rumours of long standing and statements made by a prisoner PERSON , all of direct relevance to the PERSON / PERSON - file .
CARDINAL . Rumours ( persistent ones ) had been circulating for DATE among the inmates of C wing ( the wing of ORG , a server , of PERSON , often in the workshop , of PERSON , another server ... )
according to which the former warder PERSON had not been the person who had introduced the revolver used by PERSON ...
Commentary

This literal quotation from the beginning of the statement by the Deputy Director itself demonstrates uncontradictably that there was a ‘ ORG item of evidence here , to be verified and checked in an exhaustive and thorough manner of course , as to the introduction of the revolver into the prison by some person other than PERSON .
The saying ‘ no smoke without fire’ which applies here is a vivid expression of popular wisdom .
CARDINAL . Statements made by prisoner PERSON ( to Mr Derriks on CARDINAL )
These statements are precise enough as to how the weapon was introduced :

( a ) by a woman visitor ... in the lavatory ( b ) PERSON , the deported ‘ FAC ( c ) PERSON , escaped on DATE ... ( d ) PERSON these CARDINAL were known as having made plans to escape ... ( e ) the weapon was hidden at the bottom of a dustbin .
Commentary
These CARDINAL facts mentioned above would on their own have deserved a thorough investigation ( the third fact appears believable since PERSON stated it himself ) .
CARDINAL . PERSON ’s offer to give evidence on oath - possibly at the PERSON , with reference to the correctness of the content of his statements ...
Commentary

Even if this declaration appears from his point of view to favour his request for release on licence , nothing prevented such statements and such an offer of sworn evidence at the very least engaging the attention of an impartial investigator , always hard at work in such a case to find out an undeniable method or opportunity of introducing a weapon into the prison ( by a method not involving a prison warder ) , as Mr PERSON , the acting Director of the prison , appositely said ...

The investigation appears to us to be manifestly incomplete , as the investigating judge did not consider it necessary to question PERSON before terminating the investigation , even though many facts in the case - file gave PERSON ’s statements definite verisimilitude - the possibility of an object being introduced by a woman visitor , who is not searched and has access to the lavatory ; the undoubted possibility of hiding a weapon there ( for example , securing it in the flushing system or elsewhere ) ; because of his duties in the workshop , access to whole prison by PERSON , PERSON , server , PERSON , server , obsessed with gaining freedom , as was his fellow - prisoner PERSON ( escape plans ) .
Extensive contacts between these prisoners in C wing , CARDINAL in contact DATE for TIME usually ... from TIME and from TIME , for DATE .

It follows from the above : persistent specific rumours for DATE ( PERSON did not introduce the weapon ) , statements made by a prisoner in C wing ( no doubt one prisoner among many , in view of the rumours ) , offer to testify on oath with reference to these quite precise statements , highly likely to be true at least in part , that additional investigative measures in great detail were necessary , at appropriate times and under appropriate conditions ;

The defence must deplore such a deficiency in the case- file , even though it now appears unnecessary or superfluous in view of the conclusions which now necessarily follow , after a methodical examination of all the facts which have been presented and a critical evaluation of them .
This offer to produce evidence was implicitly rejected by ORG , which did not mention it in its decision , and did not call any witnesses before giving judgment .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG , relying inter alia on Article CARDINAL paras . CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE ( d ) ( article DATE , article DATE , article CARDINAL - CARDINAL-d ) of the LAW . In an appeal comprising CARDINAL points , he criticised ORG in essence for not having replied to certain of his submissions , including his request for witnesses to be called , and for having based its decision on the extremely dubious statements of Mr PERSON and a promissory note of no probative value .
ORG dismissed the appeal on CARDINAL DATE , for the following reasons :

... The judgment states : ‘ that a detailed examination of the evidence in the case - file and of the evidence adduced at the hearing has enabled the [ ORG ] to form the conviction that the [ appellant ] is guilty of the offences as ORG and specifies the facts on which that conviction was based ;

As the court thus gave the reasons on the basis of which it formed its conviction , it was not bound to indicate the reasons for which it dismissed the application submitted to it for additional evidence to be taken , considered implicitly but clearly in its decision to be of no value in establishing the truth ;

... The submission , which ... does not state in what way ORG failed to give adequate reasons for its decision , or indicate the defence submissions or applications which the appellant put forward in his appeal and which the judgment allegedly failed to answer , is inadmissible as insufficiently specific ;

The judgment noted that the accusations made by the co - defendant PERSON against PERSON had been consistent throughout the investigation and that the statements which he had made on numerous occasions , both when questioned by the police and before the investigating judge , were precise and coherent , and considered that they were at no time improbable or incoherent , that they were , on the contrary , highly believable and capable of sustaining the conviction formed by ORG and that the appellant ’s allegations concerning the loan which he had contracted were categorically denied both by PERSON and by another inmate , a certain PERSON , and moreover were in no way consistent with the fact that the document in question was in PERSON possession ;

Where statute , as in this case , does not lay down a specific form of proof , the trial court assesses with unfettered discretion the probative value of the evidence which has been adduced before it and which the parties have been able freely to contradict ;
The judgment was therefore able , without infringing the statutory provisions cited [ by the appellant ] , to rely on the statements of a co - defendant as evidence against the appellant ;
In addition , the submission which ... amounts to criticising the appellate court ’s assessment of the facts is inadmissible ;

... It is not contradictory to consider that certain statements should be treated with caution and to find that the accusations contained in such statements were formulated consistently throughout the investigation , that they were made on numerous occasions , that they were precise , that at no time did they appear improbable or incoherent and that they were , on the contrary , highly believable and capable of sustaining the conviction formed by the court ;

... On the basis of such considerations , the judgment , which decided that ‘ the [ appellant ] unsuccessfully alleged in his submissions that PERSON statements were improbable in numerous respects and contained discrepancies’ , answered the submissions indicated in this point of the appeal ;

That the contested judgment did not base its decision on an element of fact which had been mentioned by the decisions of the investigating authorities or the trial court below does not in itself lead to the conclusion that there has been a violation of the statutory provisions relied on in the appeal ;

In so far as the judgment under appeal convicted the appellant on the basis of the statements of a co - defendant and the fact that the appellant had signed a promissory note , it gave an adequate statement of the reasons on which it was based and a justification in law for reaching its decision ;
CARDINAL . Under LAW ,
" Petty offences ( contraventions ) shall be proved by official reports or , where there are no such reports , or in support thereof , by evidence taken from witnesses .

On pain of nullity , witness evidence in addition to or contradicting the contents of official reports or reports of police officers empowered by law to make findings in respect of lesser offences and petty offences , unless it is alleged that they have been tampered with or forged , shall not be admissible . As regards reports made by other officials and officers whose reports are not regarded by the law as authoritative in the absence of such an allegation , they may be contested by written or oral evidence , if the court considers it appropriate to admit such evidence . "
This provision applies also to lesser offences ( délits correctionnels ) , under LAW .

CARDINAL . " Official reports duly drawn up are evidence of the material facts stated by the reporting officers acting within their capacities , and in particular of the reality of the declarations which they state have been made to them " , but " this probative force does not extend to the honesty of the declaration or the accuracy of the facts stated to them " ( Court of Cassation ( PERSON . ) , CARDINAL DATE , ORG , Pasicrisie ( Pas . ) , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The above - mentioned ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL " are merely declaratory " ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , PERSON , PERSON . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ) . " [ They are ] not an exhaustive list of the means whereby offences may be proved " and " [ do ] not prevent the trial court , in cases where statute does not prescribe ... a particular method of proof , reaching its conviction on the basis of all the evidence in the case which has been duly admitted and which the parties have been able to contradict " ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , PERSON , PERSON . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ; see also PERSON . , DATE , PERSON , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL , and the aforementioned ORG et PERSON judgment ) . The court may thus also " have regard to items of evidence other than official reports , other reports and the testimony of witness " ( see the above - mentioned PERSON et PERSON judgment ) .

CARDINAL . The court may base its conviction on presumptions , that is to say , on what DATE of LAW defines as " assumptions about an unknown fact which statute or the court makes on the basis of a known fact " , but under LAW it " can only admit presumptions which are serious , precise and concurring " .

Such presumptions may legally be admitted as evidence of an offence and " the court need not state its reasons for considering that the presumptions on which it bases its conviction are serious , precise and concurring " ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , PERSON , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ) : it has unfettered discretion to assess whether the items of evidence mentioned by it are of such nature ( PERSON . , DATE , PERSON , PERSON . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The court decides , again at its discretion , on " the necessity or appropriateness of an investigative measure or additional steps " ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , ORG , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ; see also PERSON . , DATE , ORG , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL , and GPE . , DATE , ORG , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ) , inter alia as to the calling of witnesses ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , ORG . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ; see also the aforementioned ORG judgment ) .

It " is empowered to determine with unfettered discretion whether , having regard to the evidence already received , further witnesses for the prosecution or the defence must be heard in order for it to form its conviction " ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , PERSON , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ; see also the aforementioned ORG judgment ) . " If it refuses such a request on the grounds that it considers the measure requested to be unnecessary for founding its conviction , it does not violate the rights of the defence " ( see the above - mentioned ORG judgment ) .

This rule applies on appeal as well as at first instance ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , Bonus , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ; PERSON . , DATE , ORG , Pas . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ; PERSON . , DATE , PERSON c. PERSON et consorts , PERSON . , DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Finally , unless statute prescribes " a particular method of proof " ( see the above - mentioned ORG and PERSON judgments ) , the trial court " assesses in unfettered discretion the probative value of the evidence in the case " : this is a " general rule with respect to the taking of evidence in criminal cases " ( see the above- mentioned ORG judgment ) .
CARDINAL . Under LAW , an appellate court may not replace an acquittal by a conviction or impose a more severe sentence on a defendant , unless its members are unanimous in reaching that decision .
